abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC) is associated with germline deleterious variants in <jats:italic>CDH1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>CTNNA1</jats:italic>. The majority of HDGC-suspected patients are still genetically unresolved, raising the need for identification of novel HDGC predisposing genes. Under the collaborative environment of the SOLVE-RD consortium, re-analysis of whole-exome sequencing data from unresolved gastric cancer cases (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 83) identified a mosaic missense variant in <jats:italic>PIK3CA</jats:italic> in a 25-year-old female with diffuse gastric cancer (DGC) without familial history for cancer. The variant, c.3140A>G p.(His1047Arg), a known cancer-related somatic hotspot, was present at a low variant allele frequency (18%) in leukocyte-derived DNA. Somatic variants in <jats:italic>PIK3CA</jats:italic> are usually associated with overgrowth, a phenotype that was not observed in this patient. This report highlights mosaicism as a potential, and understudied, mechanism in the etiology of DGC.</jats:p>

title: A mosaic PIK3CA variant in a young adult with diffuse gastric cancer: case report
